article.headline: (24) WAKE FOREST 91, APPALACHIAN ST 78
article.story:
WINSTON-SALEM, North Carolina (Ticker) -- Justin Gray is 
starting to find his game.

Gray scored 19 points as No. 24 Wake Forest continued its
non-conference success at home with a 91-78 victory over
Appalachian State.

Switched to point guard this season, Gray struggled in his first
four games before being moved back to shooting guard for
Tuesday's win over UNC Asheville.  He responded well to the
move, scoring 16 points in his last two contests.

Wake Forest coach Skip Prosser has indicated that Gray again
will play point guard this season, adding that he is confident
that the senior could excel at the position. However, Prosser
again opted to start freshman Harvey Hale at the point Friday.

Gray played well for the second straight game, scoring 14 points
in the first half to help the Demon Deacons (5-1) open a 53-37
cushion at the break.  Wake Forest shot a sizzling 64 percent
(18-of-28) in the opening half and 56 percent (29-of-52)
overall.

It was an even bigger night for Demon Deacons senior Trent
Strickland, who made his first seven shots and finished with 25
points.  He made 8-of-11 shots overall.

Led by Gray and Strickland, the Demon Deacons won for the 50th
time in their last 51 contests against non-Atlantic Coast
Conference opponents at home.   Wake Forest has won 20 in a row
overall at home.

Eric Williams added 14 points for Wake Forest, which recorded a
season-high in points. The Demon Deacons had been stagnant
offensively in their first five games.

Wake Forest improved to 19-0 all-time against Appalachian State.
The teams were meeting for the first time in 10 years.

D.J. Thompson scored 20 points to lead the Mountaineers (2-1).

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.
